channel.title: NYT > International Home
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Johnson Controls to Combine With Tyco in Tax-Inversion Deal
item.description: By moving its domicile to Ireland, the merged company will be able to save about $150 million in taxes a year.
item.dc:creator: LESLIE PICKER

item.title: Protesters in Haiti Demand That President Quit
item.description: One day earlier, officials had bowed to widespread civil unrest and postponed a single-candidate presidential runoff election that was to be held on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: A vehicle burned after an opposition rally in Port-Au-Prince, Haiti, on Friday.

item.title: Airbus to Start Talks With Iran About Buying New Jets
item.description: The orders, likely to be partly financed with loans from European export-credit agencies, could be announced as early as this week, an official said.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: An Airbus plane from the Iranian private airline Mahan Air in 2015. Iran is looking to place orders for more than 100 European-made aircraft.

item.title: Strong Earthquake Rattles Spain and Morocco
item.description: The temblor caused some material damage in southern Spain and northern Morocco, although no deaths or injuries were reported.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: East Coast Blizzard Ends but a Long Cleanup Begins
item.description: The New York region emerged with relatively little damage despite near-record accumulations. On the East Coast, 29 deaths were related to the storm.
item.dc:creator: JAMES BARRON and SARAH MASLIN NIR
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ryan Morris, center, 7, resting on a snowman at Asphalt Green, a recreation center in Manhattan. For those with no official duties, Sunday was a bright day for snowboarding and snowballs.

item.title: Match-Fixing Suspicions Raised at Australian Open After Site Stops Bets on Match
item.description: With tennis already under scrutiny over possible match fixing, money poured in on what would normally be an obscure mixed doubles match, leading Pinnacle Sports to suspend betting on it.
item.dc:creator: BEN ROTHENBERG and JAMES GLANZ
item.media:description: David Marrero, left, with his partner, Lara Arruabarrena, at the Australian Open. Marrero blamed a knee injury for their performance in a 6-0, 6-3 loss Sunday.

item.title: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Battle for Party’s Future
item.description: With many Democrats torn between pragmatism and liberalism, the question of whether the party’s left wing can become a true force again in presidential politics will soon have its first test, in Iowa.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK HEALY
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a New Deal-style liberal, at a campaign event on Sunday at Luther College in Decorah, Iowa.

item.title: Second-Year Super Bowl Advertisers Face Their Own Pressures to Succeed
item.description: Avocados From Mexico and at least two other advertisers, Skittles and Wix.com, have decided to return to the Super Bowl, indicating that live television remains important for advertisers.
item.dc:creator: SYDNEY EMBER
item.media:description: Avocados From Mexico’s 2015 Super Bowl spot featured a “draft.”

item.title: A Struggle to Quell Investor Fears Over Unsettled Emerging Markets
item.description: Traders and portfolio managers worry that sophisticated institutional investors, who generally tend to take a longer-term view, have been the ones driving the selling over the last six months.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:credit: Jodi Hilton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justin Leverenz, the head of Oppenheimer’s developing markets fund, in Turkey in 2014.

item.title: In Portugal, Voters Pick Center-Right President
item.description: The new president, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, won 52 percent of the votes, with 98 percent counted.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: China Deepens Its Footprint in Iran After Lifting of Sanctions
item.description: The countries’ strategic pact gives China a western gateway to Middle East markets, and has saved Iran from international isolation and economic ruin.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: China’s president, Xi Jinping, left, with his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Rouhani, in Tehran on Saturday.

item.title: Yarrabah Journal: Aboriginal Brass Band Offers Burst of Hope in a Bleak Community
item.description: In its own modest way, a band created during a time of Aboriginal oppression is helping to heal deep racial wounds in Australia.
item.dc:creator: CLARISSA SEBAG-MONTEFIORE
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men fishing at Wungu Beach in Yarrabah, Australia, recently.

item.title: China Considers Larger Role in Afghanistan Peace Process
item.description: One reason for China’s engagement is that a stable Afghanistan could become a critical transportation hub and market for Chinese goods.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Salahuddin Rabbani of Afghanistan, center, in Kabul last week, is beginning a visit to China on Monday.

item.title: Pentagon Wants Psychologists to End Ban on Interrogation Role
item.description: The American Psychological Association has been asked to revisit its “blanket prohibition” on the involvement of psychologists in national security interrogations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JAMES RISEN
item.media:description: The Washington headquarters of the American Psychological Association, which last summer barred psychologists from participating in national security interrogations at facilities like the Guantánamo Bay prison.

item.title: ISIS Video Appears to Show Paris Assailants Earlier in Syria and Iraq
item.description: The video appears aimed at making it clear that the assailants — some of whom had European passports — had been carrying out atrocities in the group’s name long before their return into Europe.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Egyptian Museum Officials Face Tribunal for Damaging King Tutankhamen’s Mask
item.description: Eight Egyptian officials are to face a disciplinary tribunal for their role in a botched repair job that caused lasting damage to the famed burial mask.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: The gold mask of King Tutankhamen in the Egyptian Museum in Cairo. Workers accidentally knocked the beard off in August 2014.

item.title: Italy Divided Over Effort to Legalize Civil Unions for Gays
item.description: Years after a similar effort failed, lawmakers are confronting an issue that remains a wide divide between Italy and most of the rest of the West.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Supporters of same-sex civil union kissed holding clocks “to wake up Italy” on Saturday near the Pantheon in central Rome.

item.title: Europe’s Top Digital-Privacy Watchdog Zeros In on U.S. Tech Giants
item.description: Whether or not negotiators reach a pact by Feb. 1 on how companies like Google and Facebook use Europeans’ online data, Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin is in a position to propel privacy protection efforts.
item.category: Commission Nationale de l'Informatique et des Libertes (CNIL)
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin, empowered by Europe’s highest court, will be at the heart of efforts to police how digital data is transferred outside of the European Union.

item.title: 3 Inmates Who Escaped From California Jail Considered Armed
item.description: Investigators are pursuing several leads in the search for three inmates who masterminded a brazen escape from a Southern California maximum-security jail and are considered dangerous, authorities said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Massachusetts Chief’s Tack in Drug War: Steer Addicts to Rehab, Not Jail
item.description: Approaching addiction as a disease, the Gloucester Police Department became the unusual law enforcement agency offering heroin users an alternative to prison.
item.dc:creator: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leonard Campanello, the police chief in Gloucester, Mass., is spearheading an effort to guide addicts toward treatment instead of arresting them.
